==Countries affected==
==Countries affected==
Similar protests actually took place in almost all Arab countries<ref>{{cite web|author=By AA Sheikh |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/121796/the-potato-revolution/ |title=The potato revolution â The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=2011-02-19 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> from [[Morocco]] to [[Iraq]], as well as in other states, ranging from [[Gabon]] to [[Albania]], [[Iran]] and [[Kazakhstan]], to [[China]]. China has censored most media coverage of the Arab worldâs popular revolt of the last few weeks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jasmine-revolution-coverage-censored-china-159665 |title='Jasmine Revolution' Coverage Censored in China |publisher=The Hollywood Reporter |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> leading to difficulty in organizing Jasmine protests in China.<ref>{{cite web|author=ByÂ  Jaime FlorCruz, CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/02/20/china.protests/ |title='Jasmine' protests in China fall flat |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
Similar protests actually took place in almost all Arab countries<ref>{{cite web|author=By AA Sheikh |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/121796/the-potato-revolution/ |title=The potato revolution â The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=2011-02-19 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> from [[Morocco]] to [[Iraq]], as well as in other states, ranging from [[Gabon]] to [[Albania]], [[Iran]] and [[Kazakhstan]], to [[China]]. China has censored most media coverage of the Arab worldâs popular revolt of the last few weeks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jasmine-revolution-coverage-censored-china-159665 |title='Jasmine Revolution' Coverage Censored in China |publisher=The Hollywood Reporter |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> leading to difficulty in organizing Jasmine protests in China.<ref>{{cite web|author=ByÂ  Jaime FlorCruz, CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/02/20/china.protests/ |title='Jasmine' protests in China fall flat |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
â   â
===China===
  â
[[China's Jasmine revolution]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Catholic Online |url=http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=40437 |title=Unrest in Arab world spreads to China - International - Catholic Online |publisher=Catholic.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> has also brought the Chinese government into action. Chinese security officials questioned or detained<ref>{{cite web|author=Tania Branigan in Beijing and agencies |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/20/chinese-officials-detain-activists-protests |title=China detains activists after online call for protests | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> scores of activists and warned others against staging protests after an online call was made for demonstrations in 13 cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/20/unrest-morocco-iran-algeria-yemen-china |title=Anger on the streets: unrest in Iran, Algeria, Yemen, Morocco and China | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> Protesters are calling for weekly events. <ref>{{cite web|author=globalpost newsdesk|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/asia-pacific/china/110223/china-jasmine-revolution-protests-sunday |title=China: Jasmine Revolution protests to be held every Sunday |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
  â
[[File:Voa beijing 230 20feb11.jpg|thumb|The largely silent crowd gathered in front of a [[McDonalds]] restaurant near [[Tiananmen Square]] in [[Beijing]].]]
  â
[[PRC Government]] officials arrested activists, added to the normal police presence, disabled some [[Mobile phone industry in China|cell phone]] [[text messaging]] services and [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|deleted Internet postings]] about protests planned for 14:00 on 20 February in [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]] and 11 other cities.<ref name="China tries to stamp out">{{cite news| url= http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-02-20-china-jasmine-revolution_N.htm| title= China tries to stamp out 'Jasmine Revolution'| publisher= [[usatoday.com]]| date= 20 Feb 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> On the day of the protests, the police turned out en masse to all of the potential protest locations.<ref name="NYChina">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/21/world/asia/21china.html|title=Chinese Security Officials Respond to Call for Protests|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|author=Jacob, Andrew|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Small crowds, including quite a few curious onlookers, gathered at the planned site in [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]] but did not chant slogans or hold signs.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8336611/China-snuffs-out-democracy-protests.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Peter | last1=Foster | first2=Malcolm | last2=Moore | title=China snuffs out democracy protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12517909 | work=BBC News | title=China police break up 'protests' after online appeal | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Saiget |first=Robert |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iblKmk0zFyrloDdKUWP56cuOfD2Q?docId=CNG.7a0509e93accafbdfd4785aad6cc3018.5b1 |title=AFP: China cracks down after calls for protests |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/20/us-china-protests-idUSTRE71J0TV20110220 | work=Reuters | title=Chinese police snuff out planned Arab-inspired protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  â   â
China also blocked coverage of the protests in the Arab world that continued after Mubarak's fall.<ref>{{cite web|author=5:31 AM ET |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-21/china-blocks-coverage-of-protests-to-squelch-egypt-style-revolt.html |title=China Blocks Coverage of `Jasmine Revolution' Protests, Arrests Activists |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
  â   â
President [[Hu Jintao]] responded by calling top leaders into a "study session" to root out and tackle social issues before they "become threats to stability".<ref name="NYChina"/> In a speech at the [[Central Party School of the Communist Party of China|Central Party School]], Hu called out for tighter restrictions to the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703498804576156203874160350.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Call for Protests Unnerves China|author=Page, Jeremy|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> On February 18, an architect of the country's Internet monitoring software told a state newspaper that the program, already regarded as among the most stringent in the world, should be strengthened.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/02/20/2076764/china-cracks-down-on-protest-threats.html#ixzz1EYFczpfX |title=China cracks down on protest threats, rounds up dissidents|Publisher=Miami Herald Media|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  â   â
Opposition leaders there have supported [[China's Jasmine revolution]] for the democracy movements in the Middle East and Mainland China.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.rti.org.tw/Content/GetSingleNews.aspx?ContentID=120031 |title=Radio Taiwan International |publisher=English.rti.org.tw |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref>
 
===Iran===
===Iran===
